docs.lead_paragraph: The push to censor information on the Internet to citizens beyond the European Union is a troubling idea.

headline.main: Europe’s Expanding ‘Right to Be Forgotten’

docs.abstract: Editorial warns that European officials and regulators who are pushing for search engine companies like Google to remove global results under its new 'right to be forgotten' principle is opening door to greater censorship of the Internet across the globe; raises possibility that autocratic regimes will use precedent to justify whitewashing history, and that precedent will give companies power to determine when censorship is legitimate or not.

headline.main: A Prickly Partnership for Uber and Google

docs.abstract: Google and Uber have prickly relationship in which they need each other, but are said to be developing products that could compete with the others; Google invested more than $250 million in Uber in 2013; in five years they could be in marketing battle over car-pooling and mapping apps, delivery services and other products.

headline.main: Google, Mighty Now, but Not Forever
headline.print_headline: Google, Mighty Now, but Not Forever

docs.abstract: Farhad Manjoo State of the Art column examines whether Google is falling into same trap of eventual technological irrelevancy that snared previous tech giants like Digital Equipment and Wang; notes tech analyst Ben Thompson has garnered attention for pointing out correctly that Google's ad business seems to have peaked, and suggests that without new source of revenue company could fall behind its competitors.

docs.snippet: Every tweet, video or comment online has branding power, just like ads on television or online. In a measure of media value that included conversations on Twitter, Facebook, news sites, Google Plus and blogs, the N.F.L. joined four media giants in...
docs.lead_paragraph: Every tweet, video or comment online has branding power, just like ads on television or online. In a measure of media value that included conversations on Twitter, Facebook, news sites, Google Plus and blogs, the N.F.L. joined four media giants in the $1 billion-plus club. Starbucks, at No. 11, captured $560 million in equivalent value in 2014.

headline.main: Hoping Google’s Lab Is a Rainmaker
headline.print_headline: Hoping Google’s Lab Is a Rainmaker

docs.abstract: Wall Street investors, who have patiently bore increase in Google's research and development spending, are nervously waiting for company's science projects to reap rewards; many are worried after failure of Google's Internet-connected glasses and fact that other planned projects, like its driverless cars, could take years to launch.

docs.abstract: Car dealerships around nation will soon start selling vehicles equipped to run dashboard systems with Google and Apple smartphone technology; systems for maps, music and more will essentially take over driver's center screen and various buttons in car; autos are latest obsession for Silicon Valley.

docs.lead_paragraph: Google’s sometimes testy relationship with community leaders in Mountain View, Calif., a city already bursting at the seams, is likely to get testier.

headline.main: Google Plans New Headquarters, and a City Fears Being Overrun

docs.abstract: Mountain View Journal; Google's expected proposal for expanded new headquarters in Mountain View, Calif, is likely to strain already aggravated relationship between company and community leaders who want to curb growth of city; while Google has been boon to city's tax revenues, employment rate and real estate prices, many residents are wary of city's rapid growth; other cities that house tech giants face similar dilemma.
